node.title: Family Stress Intensifies as Omicron Invades the Holidays
node.alt: Katherine Sargent, right, with her daughters Matilda, left, and Ena, at home in Portland, Maine. “It’s a lot of pressure to want to give your children so much magic and warmth right now, with so many limitations,” Ms. Sargent said.
node.description: Some people are resigned to another season of restrictions and plan to forge ahead with celebrations. Others are trying to overcome a sense of perpetual fear.
node.content: ["A single mother of two girls, Katherine Sargent is accustomed to working hard to ensure Christmas is a wonderful time, baking cookies and shopping with her children to find new ornaments for the tree.", "She had hoped that this season would be more cheerful than in 2020, when schools were shuttered and the Covid-19 vaccine rollout had barely begun.", "But it hasn\u2019t turned out that way.", "Even though more people are returning to normal life in her hometown, Portland, Maine, they\u2019re finding there\u2019s little normal about it. \u201cThey lack the energy to get together, to celebrate,\u201d Ms. Sargent said. \u201cSo many people I know say they\u2019re stressed.\u201d", "This year is indeed bringing a new layer of stressors, especially now that the highly contagious Omicron variant is casting a chill on travel and everyday routines. Once again, we\u2019re dialing back on plans to attend parties, concerts and movies. We\u2019re Googling the variant\u2019s symptoms and taking our temperatures. And the nation\u2019s mental health is at a precarious level.", "On top of pandemic pressures, inflation has driven up the prices of many gifts. Shelves remain barren in many toy stores as popular dolls and games sit aboard container ships in traffic jams offshore from the nation\u2019s ports.", "Add to that the traditional hassles of tangled light strings and fraught family relations, and it\u2019s no wonder that holiday Grump Trees are selling fast at Trader Joe\u2019s.", "\u201cWe entered into this winter feeling more optimistic, and now it\u2019s clear the uncertainty continues,\u201d said Vaile Wright, a clinical psychologist and senior director for health care innovation at the American Psychological Association. A recent study for the group showed that people were having trouble making the most basic decisions.", "And the rules keep changing for family gatherings, with rapid virus tests in higher demand than gifts in some places. \u201cCovid definitely adds a complexity to the holidays that wasn\u2019t there a few years ago,\u201d said Tracey Kim Snow, a clinical psychologist in the Chicago area.", "Even among the closest of relatives, the vaccination divide has caused hurt and isolation. Some families have forbidden immediate relatives from visiting if they aren\u2019t immunized against Covid. And some have gone even further by demanding their relatives get booster shots for inclusion around the tree to enjoy the collective excitement of unwrapping presents.", "\u201cOnce again, we\u2019re looking at other humans as a risk, and we weren\u2019t trained to do that, except in battle,\u201d said Dr. Cynthia Ackrill, a lifestyle medicine physician in Asheville, N.C.", "Ms. Sargent, 37, shifted to remote work to avoid exposure to the virus these past few weeks, so that she could be with her grandmother along with her parents, her brother and his family for the holiday.", "Divorced six years ago, she finds that being a single mother adds extra strain to her planning for a second Christmas in the pandemic.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a lot of pressure to want to give your children so much magic and warmth right now, with so many limitations, and I don\u2019t have a partner to share it with,\u201d Ms. Sargent said. ", "One survey conducted for the American Psychiatric Association found that women were feeling more stress this holiday season compared with last year\u2019s.", "The same was true for adults ages 18 to 44, Republican and Independent voters and those with incomes under $50,000, according to the poll of 2,119 adults conducted last month.", "The tensions are evident in national warnings about the nation\u2019s mental health and as counselors have been hearing from and seeing more patients and newcomers. Ms. Snow, a psychologist in the Chicago area, said appointments started increasing in numbers right after Thanksgiving.", "Dr. Itai Danovitch, chairman of the psychiatry and behavioral neurosciences department at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, said patients were experiencing twin worries from the pandemic and the holidays. \u201cThose two things colliding increase the background stress,\u201d he said.", "In counseling patients about Covid, Dr. Danovitch added, \u201cI see both people who have resigned themselves to the new norm, and also people who are in a perpetual state of fear.\u201d", "Therapists offer a variety of tips and exercises to ease stress, often advising simple tasks like looking for activities to distract people from the pandemic and not watching anxiety-producing news.", "Drinking too much and smoking too much cannabis should be avoided, Dr. Danovitch said. He suggests searching for ways to be of service in your community by volunteering for a worthy cause or checking in with an older neighbor.", "Because holiday meals are well-known minefields for family tension, try to plan ahead for how to defuse those arguments, said Dr. Ackrill, a fellow with the American Institute of Stress and an editor of its magazine Contentment.", "\u201cMaybe a long walk before dinner,\u201d she said. \u201cIf you can get outside, that\u2019s a great idea. Play a game together. Build in some fun.\u201d", "And if the family starts discussing divisive topics over the cranberry sauce? Merely point out that people at the table have different viewpoints, she said.", "Other simple steps can ease stress: going to bed 15 minutes earlier, taking breaks during the day \u2014 even if it\u2019s just walking around or doing jumping jacks \u2014 or watching a funny four-minute video for a laugh, she advised.", "Another tool is breath work, a technique of using controlled breathing to calm yourself.", "For some, the holidays can stir up painful memories that require regular counseling.", "\u201cIf that anxiety is really spinning out of control, there\u2019s a threshold where you should seek help,\u201d Dr. Danovitch said.", "Kathi Nausedas, of Lockport, Ill., a Chicago suburb, is preparing for the second Christmas since her mother\u2019s death, and the second after her husband filed for divorce. She is trying to shield her two young daughters \u2014 Ava, 9, and Audra, 7 \u2014 from the process.", "\u201cThat first year, I was really scared to face the holidays,\u201d Ms. Nausedas said. \u201cI was afraid to do all the things I love, like listening to the Christmas music on the radio. The first time it came on the radio, I would cry.\u201d", "Her mother\u2019s birthday was Christmas Eve, adding to the sense of loss.", "She sought out counseling with a therapist who has taught her to be easier on herself, she said. Still, Ms. Nausedas, a special-education teacher in the public schools, has worried about how she would pay for presents this year. (She had to wait until her latest paycheck on Friday to start shopping.)", "\u201cMy daughters are so grateful for anything,\u201d Ms. Nausedas said. \u201cI think I can make anything work, and just be creative in whatever I do. They\u2019re the best.\u201d", "Still, as Omicron spreads, she has learnedof additional tasks that will be required for work. Teachers in her school district have been asked to prepare two weeks of lesson packets in case they have to return to virtual teaching.", "If her daughters\u2019 school district also shifts to remote learning, she would be helping them and teaching classes at the same time \u2014 a balancing act she has done before and dreads repeating.", "For Mary Janevic, 52, of Ann Arbor, Mich., music provides a centerpiece to family celebrations, with all three of her teenagers playing musical instruments and entertaining gatherings with favorites like \u201cWe Three Kings,\u201d \u201cSilent Night\u201d and \u201cThe Little Drummer Boy.\u201d", "Ms. Janevic has survived other holidays filled with sorrow; a daughter, Laila, became ill with a rare form of lymphoma at age 3 on Christmas Day 18 years ago and died six months later.", "\u201cWe were sort of reeling for a while,\u201d Ms. Janevic said. But as time goes on, the more positive happy memories tend to surface, she said. \u201cAnd there\u2019s a tunnel to the past that tends to be present at the holidays.\u201d", "Ms. Janevic is well aware of the Omicron variant, as an associate research scientist in health behavior and education at the University of Michigan School of Public Health.", "She and her husband, Robert Wierenga, 52, can still carry on with what she calls a textbook Midwestern Christmas: cookies, opening presents on Christmas morning and wearing their pajamas all day. She will bake her mother\u2019s mint meringue cookies with chocolate chips and green food coloring.", "And, in a bow to Omicron, Ms Janevic said, her family is now planning to use rapid tests before a Christmas Eve gathering with relatives and before visiting her 92-year-old aunt.", "In Portland, Ms. Sargent\u2019s two daughters, ages 9 and 10, experienced an unconventional form of holiday glee by getting their second Covid vaccine shots.", "\u201cBefore they went, they said they were so excited,\u201d Ms. Sargent said. \u201cI didn\u2019t know it would mean so much to them. They were both so happy.\u201d"]
